awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Controlling the properties of oxide-encapsulated metals for interfacial catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Solid catalysts play an important role in energy-efficient commercial processes used to produce fuels, chemicals, and energy, and also in pollution mitigation. Most commercial solid catalysts used today consist of metal particles supported on high surface area support materials. Improvements in these catalysts are needed to further improve their efficiency. Successful research in this area results in lower energy consumption and reduced environmental impact of many chemical processes. One approach to this goal is through control of the interfaces between the metal particles and the support materials. In this project, Dr. Nikolla (Wayne State University) and Dr. Medlin (University of Colorado) are developing an understanding these metal/support interfaces with the objective of discovering more active and efficient catalysts. Dr. Nikolla and Dr. Medlin actively engage in outreach activities related to the education of young students, especially those from underrepresented groups. For example, they are developing workshops for underrepresented K-12 female students to enhance their understanding and desire in pursuing higher education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. Dr. Nikolla and Dr. Medlin are also designing activities to inform parents about STEM fields, so that the parents can encourage their children to pursue STEM education.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Eranda Nikolla of Wayne State University and Dr. Will Medlin of University of Colorado are developing an understanding of solid metal/metal oxide interfaces in "inverted" catalytic systems with the objective of enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity in chemical reactions. They are synthesizing controlled metal oxide-encapsulated metal nanoparticles (i.e., M@MO structures) with systematic variations in structure and composition of both the metal and metal oxide components.  The research team correlates these synthetic variations to the surface chemical properties and catalyst performance. Fundamental insights from experimental model catalysts coupled with advanced characterization and computational studies on inverted catalyst systems are being used to advance the understanding of interfacial chemistry. The encapsulated catalyst systems are also being investigated as a platform for controlling the near-surface environment around the reactive interface through functionalization of the oxide pores with organic ligands.  Dr. Nikolla and Dr. Medlin are actively engaged with educational and research outreach activities aimed at inspiring and informing undergraduate and K-12 female students from underrepresented groups regarding STEM fields and research in the area of catalysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a joint effort between the Nikolla laboratory at Wayne State University, which then moved to the University of Michigan and Medlin laboratory at the University of Colorado-Boulder.  The project focused on developing an understanding of solid metal/metal oxide interfaces in “inverted” and multifunctional catalytic systems with the objective of enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity in chemical reactions. The objective was to synthesize controlled metal oxide-metal interfaces (i.e., M@MO core-shell structures) with systematic variations in structure and composition of both the metal and metal oxide components and link these variations to the surface chemical properties and catalyst performance. We successfully synthesized a series of M@MO structures with systematic variation in the nature of the oxide (TiO2, CeO2 and ZrO2). We found that in general independent of the nature of the oxide shell, the “inverted” catalytic systems displayed higher activity and stability than conventional supported catalysts due to unique physicochemical properties at the Pd-MO interface for CO oxidation reaction. Among the variations in the oxide shells considered, we found that the metal nanoparticles encapsulated by amorphous zirconia were significantly more active at low temperatures for CO oxidation reaction, presenting catalytically interesting systems for oxidation reactions under mild conditions. We found that considerable, reversible restructuring of metal active sites occurred in encapsulated structures, as observed during alternating oxidizing/reducing pre-treatments of TiO2-encapsulated Pd nanoparticles. Metal redispersion was also observed under CO oxidation reaction conditions in the encapsulated systems and was found to be a function of the nature of the oxide shell. Along the same lines, through a collaborative effort with the Pagan group at University of Puerto Rico–Mayaguez, we designed multifunctional earth-abundant molybdenum oxide based heterogeneous catalysts that are active, selective, and stable for the cleavage of vicinal C-O bonds in biomass-derived polyols. These catalysts contained a hydrogen dissociating metal coupled with MoOx on a high surface area reducible oxide support (TiO2). We showed that the support, TiO2, facilitated communication between the hydrogen dissociating metal and dispersed MoOx sites through hydrogen spillover.

One graduate student at Wayne State University and one at the University of Michigan from the Nikolla group along with one graduate student from the Medlin group were involved with this project.  Undergraduate students at each institution participated in this work, among these two female undergraduate students at Wayne State University and University of Michigan gained exposure to scientific research through this project.  We also established collaborative efforts with a minority serving institution, University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez, with the objective of establishing an exchange student program to bring minority students at the University of Michigan.


Last Modified: 03/22/2024
Modified by: Eranda Nikolla

This project was a joint effort between the Nikolla laboratory at Wayne State University, which then moved to the University of Michigan and Medlin laboratory at the University of Colorado-Boulder. The project focused on developing an understanding of solid metal/metal oxide interfaces in inverted and multifunctional catalytic systems with the objective of enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity in chemical reactions. The objective was to synthesize controlled metal oxide-metal interfaces (i.e., M@MO core-shell structures) with systematic variations in structure and composition of both the metal and metal oxide components and link these variations to the surface chemical properties and catalyst performance. These catalysts contained a hydrogen dissociating metal coupled with MoOxon a high surface area reducible oxide support (TiO2). We showed that the support, TiO2, facilitated communication between the hydrogen dissociating metal and dispersed MoOxsites through hydrogen spillover.


One graduate student at Wayne State University and one at the University of Michigan from the Nikolla group along with one graduate student from the Medlin group were involved with this project. Undergraduate students at each institution participated in this work, among these two female undergraduate students at Wayne State University and University of Michigan gained exposure to scientific research through this project.
